* He had seen the expression in which Tavatron had given him, one that 
seemed to ask if he was either insane or to at least explain his actions.
But he uttered not a sound as he looked off towards the horizon, a rather 
collective and melancholy expression on his own features.
	The sun was just now beginning to highlight the very fringes of the eastern 
borders, the wisps of white clouds turning the soft shades of orange and 
red, the further tufts of white expressing into a more purple shade.
It was indeed a sunrise, but one he had seen many times and was nothing new.
Indeed the sun would rise this day, as it did every other.
Sinking into the vast beyond in the evenings, leaving a trail of it�s light 
as a promise to return again, and then shine forth with timeless harmony of 
a promise kept.
It was a never-ending cycle, one that would go on for billions of 
solar-cycles to come. And one the humans would forever take for granted, or 
at least the majority of them.
	But now the sun was close to breaking the surface of the east, in one burst 
of light it would shine forth and present the brilliance of a new morning on 
Earth.
Dinobot simply watched the eastern border for a few moments longer; no other 
sound other then the flapping of a dragons wings. Simple silence, just as it 
was so many solar-cycles ago where there was only one objective: Find the 
Matrix.
In which he never did.
And there was no chance he would die again as honorably as he had the first 
time, but also refused to die in the first place.
But even now, his rage towards the Matrix gone, tucked away in the shadows 
of his mind once again, there was still one question, which he didn�t know 
if it could ever be answered.
Which he spoke out loud�*

� If I wish to die, why do I wish to live?�

* He had received the honored death in which he had always dreamed of in his 
past life, but he had not been admitted into that shining place in which 
every transformer was destined to be if they had followed the right path, 
instead he had wondered both space and time for an uncountable number of 
years and found out the meaning of true loneliness.
Dinobot knew what it was like to be truly alone, with no hope of ever 
reaching a destination.
And he didn�t wish to experience such a fate again, though in the end of 
this life he may be forced to do so�again.
If there was a Matrix out there, then he did not find it.
But it still tugged on his mind if he WAS supposed to find it?
Perhaps death was not meant for him then, so he was pushed back here.
Perhaps he was meant to find something that he had been looking for his 
entire life?
Perhaps simply to finish the war he and others had started?
Whatever the reason, he was here now. And he guessed that was all that 
mattered.
But he HAD been cheated as well, denied the place in the heavens as a 
remembered hero. And instead, hauled to this place once again, to continue 
the Beast Wars.
It was confusing, but it also made a bit of sense as well.
It was only right for one to finish what they helped create, but what would 
happen after that?
Would he then go on and live out his life back on Cybertron, or even here? 
Or would the Matrix finally summon his spark and he would finally be 
admitted into its hold as he was destined to be?
Either was fairly suitable to him, but which he preferred�he could not say.
Indeed he wanted what was rightfully due, but he also didn�t wish to leave.
There was far too much for him here now, he couldn�t just leave.
Dinobot looked over at Tavatron just as the sun broke the eastern horizon in 
one single burst of light, simply looking at her.
No, he couldn�t leave now, not with one whom seemed to care about him so.
It wouldn�t be fair to either party.
However, he was still a little hot that the Matrix had to go on and dump him 
back here, right into the center of the same was as when he died.
But he was here now and there wasn�t a slag that he could do about it, which 
left him with one last alternative.
Live it out and see what happens in the end, and that was about all he could 
do.
	Dinobot could feel the bunching and relaxing muscles of Necromancer 
underneath his clawed feet, but knew from their change of altitude that they 
were landing.
But he had completed his mission; he had gotten Tavatron, with help, back to 
the Cybertronian Fire.
And once she was inside a CR chamber and fully healed, all would be fine.
But then, as Necromancer came to land and stop abruptly, Dinobot dug his 
claws into the scales of his back, but they were thick enough that the great 
drak wouldn�t feel it.
He had felt Necromancer come to a stop and had watched Tavatron take a dive 
into the dirt, him staying securely in place until the dragon had come to a 
full stop.
Dinobot unhooked his claws from Necromancer�s scales and simply walked 
towards and down the living ramp in which he had created for them.
Dinobot leaned his head over one he stood in the center of the draks head, 
peering into the huge eye. *

� My appreciation for the lift.�

* And simply with that, he jumped swiftly from Necromancers skull and 
plodded over towards Tavatron and Foxfinger.
His systems were doing rather well for a bot whose fourth fluid pump was 
ready and able to go offline
But there was one thing he knew for sure if not anything else, the second he 
transformed into robot mode that pump would deactivate.
Something that he wasn�t looking forward to. *
